pages.text: Elaphrosaurus bambergi was a species of noasaurid theropod dinosaur that lived during the Late Jurassic period (around 154 - 150 million years ago). Its remains were first found in Tanzania in 1910, at the famous Tendaguru Formation. The 6 metre long animal's slender, lightweight, long-legged anatomy suggests that it was likely a fast runner.

Its classification has been changed a lot over the decades, from an early Ornithomimid, to a "Coelurid", to a late-surviving Coelophysoid. Now however it is considered an early noasaurid ceratosaurian, closely related to Limusaurus. And much like Limusaurus, it was most likely either an omnivore or a herbivore.
